## Concept

\begin{definition}[Counting Processes]
A random process $\{N(t), t \in [0,\infty) \}$ is a counting process if,
\begin{enumerate}
\item $N(0) = 0$.
\item $N(t) \in \{0,1,2,3,4,...\}$ and is non-decreasing.
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Poisson Processes]
A random process $N(t)$ is a poisson process with rate $\lambda$ if,
\begin{enumerate}
\item $N(t)$ has independent increments. That is the set $N(t_j+s_j)-N(t_j) ,~ j \in \{0,1,2,...,n\}$ is independent for each non-overlapping increment $(t_j, t_j+s_j]$.
\item For all $ t \geq 0$ and $h >0$ ,  $N(t+h) -N(t)  \sim POIS(\Lambda)$ where $\Lambda = \int_t^{t+h} \lambda (z) dz$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
